# The `Argument` Class Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

This class represents an incoming formal argument to a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function">Function</a>. <a href="#details">More...</a>

## Description {#details}

This class represents an incoming formal argument to a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function">Function</a>.

A formal argument, since it is &#96;â€˜formal`&#39;, does not contain an actual value but instead represents the type, argument number, and attributes of an argument for a specific function. When used in the body of said function, the argument of course represents the value of the actual argument that the function was called with.

Definition at line 31 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/argument-h">Argument.h</a>.

<MemberDefinition

Return the index of this formal argument in its containing function.

For example in &quot;void foo(int a, float b)&quot; a is 0 and b is 1.

### getDereferenceableOrNullBytes() {#a5b06db40548ac13bc6f5e9c41cf48f10}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>uint64&#95;t Argument::getDereferenceableOrNullBytes () const</>}>
If this argument has the dereferenceable&#95;or&#95;null attribute, return the number of bytes known to be dereferenceable.

Otherwise, zero is returned.

### hasNonNullAttr() {#a4ab8479e06d277e9e2036a17d37beafb}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool Argument::hasNonNullAttr (bool AllowUndefOrPoison=<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/basicaliasanalysis-cpp/#af6d5cafbdfc5313e65d990120021a3ec">true</a>) const</>}>
Return true if this argument has the nonnull attribute.

Also returns true if at least one byte is known to be dereferenceable and the pointer is in addrspace(0). If AllowUndefOrPoison is true, respect the semantics of nonnull attribute and return true even if the argument can be undef or poison.
